section.title: Format Tables
section.para: To control the overall width of a table and the width of each column, use the following markup:
section.programlisting:
Table Using Percentage Widths
Verb URI RegEx Default
&GET; /v\d+\.\d+/* /v\d+\.\d+/(\d+/domains).* 5/second
&POST; /v\d+\.\d+/* /v\d+\.\d+/(\d+/domains).* 2/second
&PUT; /v\d+\.\d+/* /v\d+\.\d+/(\d+/domains).* 5/second
&DELETE; /v\d+\.\d+/* /v\d+\.\d+/(\d+/domains).* 50/minute
section.para: When you create a table, check its appearance in all generated output formats. Column widths that are appropriate in HTML output might be unusable in PDF output. You can describe a table differently for each output format; see Troubleshooting badly formatted tables.

section.title: PROBLEM 3: long URLs don't wrap inside table cell
section.para: DocBook can generate linebreaks at a space or a slash, but not at a period such as in verylongdescriptivenameofaresource.com. In HTML output, the table cell simply becomes wide enough to hold the whole thing, even if that's huge; In PDF output, that doesn't happen. This causes long URLs in a table in a PDF to be wider than the table cell that contains them, which causes them to overstrike the contents of an adjacent cell or to disappear off the edge of the page. To some extent, that's just that; DocBook doesn't involve itself in linebreaks, and people gripe and struggle with that at http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4350788/xsl-fo-force-wrap-on-table-entries and elsewhere.
Two things can help: turning the table and lying about the table's size.

section.title: SOLUTION TO PROBLEM 3: Turn the table and give it a crazy size.
section.para: Because the URLs can't wrap to a new line within a cell until they hit a space or slash, letting the table size itself naturally is unreadable in the generated PDF.

Turning the table on its side helped a little, since it meant I could lose a separate column for version, but it still left some impolite overflow into the neighbor's yard. By specifying column widths that add up to greater than 100% of the space reserved for the table, it got better enough to publish.

This pushes the rightmost column all the way to the physical edge of the page. 13+32+32+32 is 109%, but who's counting? section.title: Build failure due to date format
Problem
section.para: An old draft document uses an old version of the DocBook plugin, probably 1.0.2-SNAPSHOT. Changing its pom.xml to use the current version of the DocBook plugin, such as 1.0.4, causes the build to fail.
mvn clean install -X generates mountains of unhelpful debug info, with this near the end:
Bad Month value
[INFO] BUILD FAILURE
[INFO] Total time: 6.871s
[INFO] Finished at: Wed Jul 27 15:24:56 CDT 2011
[INFO] Final Memory: 5M/81M

[ERROR] Failed to execute goal com.rackspace.cloud.api:clouddocs-maven-plugin:1.0.4:generate-pdf (default) on project cbs-ext-docs: Failed to transform rax-cbs.xml. Processing terminated by xsl:message at line 126 -> [Help 1]

org.apache.maven.lifecycle.LifecycleExecutionException: Failed to execute goal com.rackspace.cloud.api:clouddocs-maven-plugin:1.0.4:generate-pdf (default) on project cbs-ext-docs: Failed to transform rax-cbs.xml.

section.title: Solution
section.para: "Bad Month value" is the key.
Prior to 1.0.4, the publication date was expressed as mm/dd/yy; since then, it's expressed as yyyy-mm-dd, and the old format causes the build to fail.
In <book><info> find <pubdate>. Be sure it's shaped like <pubdate>2011-07-22</pubdate>. Then retry the build.

section.title: Build failure due to Maven settings
section.para: Hide settings.xml so it's not found by a project that doesn't like it; bring settings.xml back so it is found by a project that does like it. Troubleshooting build failures includes 2 scripts to do those things.
